I'm swatching for the Everyday Cardigan using Peace Fleece in urlLink Ancient Fern (worsted weight). Both swatches were made using 5 stitches of garter on the edges and 20 of stockinette in the center. Here's the scoop: Before washing: Size 8 needles: 4 stitches (exactly!), and 6 rows to the inch. Size 6 needles: 4 stitches (ditto w/above), and 8 rows to the inch After washing: Size 8 needles: 4 stitches in 1 1/8th inches. Still 6 rows in 1 inch. Size 6 needles: remained the same as before washing. The gauge for the pattern is 4 stitches per inch in stockinette on size 8 needles. My question to The Experts among us is this....does the 1/8th inch extra on the size 8's matter? Is that something I can take care of with proper blocking? Or should I go with size 6 needles? If so, do I then use still smaller needles for the ribbing? Should I have the steak, or the lobster? Red or white wine? Should I kiss on the first date? Do these pants make my butt look big? Decisions, decisions...

Hank vs Skein This is how I am using these terms: a hank or reeled hank is how PF comes. It is a figure eight looking twist of yarn that when you untwist it you have a circle or "0" or ring of yarn that has ties around it to keep the wool together until it is wound into a ball. A skein or "pull" skein is wound at the factory into a ball looking or sausage-shaped looking hunk of wool that you can use right away without further winding...Just pull the starter strand from the center of the skein. If you are going to wash your hanks, leave the ties on and add a couple more. It keeps the ring of wool neat and easier to wind into balls after it dries. Things can get VERY tangled if you don't pay attention and take your time, but the task is quite easy. If you have anxiety about this just wash one skein to try it out and you will be rewarded with soft, nice smelling fiber which will make the knitting even dreamier.

Wash BEFORE Knitting Response to "barnyard smelling" Peace Fleece: The Peace Fleece comes in reeled hanks as opposed to "pull" skeins. I DON'T use a washing machine, I un-twist the hanks and put them in a sink of warm water with maybe 2-4 drops of mild dish liquid and gently squeeze the soapy water through the yarn. Then I drain the sink and fill with clear (no soap) water and squeeze it through the yarn, do this as many times as it takes to get the soap out. On the last rinse I do the cream rinse thing(about teaspoon), rinse once more. I then place the hanks in a pillow case and let my washing machine SPIN ONLY all the excess water out. Then I drape the hanks over a line to dry. Since I live in upstate NY where it is still quite cold, I used the line in the basement. Outside in good weather would be faster. Should dry in about 24 hours. This worked beautifully for my Rogue Hoodie, which I also over-dyed because the Moscow Magic Pink was too flesh toned for me. So if you don't like your color, dye it!

I've noticed that some PF has a second label on it that it has been pre-washed. So I inquired to the PF folks why this would be. They kindly responded as follows: Dear Mary Beth, Once not to long ago our mill that spins our wool, Harrisville Designs, spun some yarn with a broken steamer. The result was a yarn that was overspun and had an overtwist. So Harrisville volunteered to wash all the skeins, approximately 3600 skeins. The result was a good example of how our wool looks after wasking with a nice loft. I wish we could afford to wash all of our yard before selling but the result is the same after it is knit up and then the garment washed. Best, Peter Interesting, huh? So this might explain why some folks aren't noticing the smell - perhaps theirs has been washed already. Also, it was reassuring to hear him mention knitting up and then washing the garment, which is what I did with Sassy (who is still a little damp, three days later). Happy knitting.
